titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the DeVane Lecture Series, Yale University, Audiorecordings
DeVane Lecture Series, Yale University, Audiorecordings
titlestmt.author: compiled by Daniel Hartwig

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday January 11, 2019 at 09:43

did.unittitle: DeVane Lecture Series, Yale University, audiorecordings

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The materials consist of audiorecordings of lectures and discussion sessions from Yale University's DeVane Lecture Series.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Forms part of Yale Record Group 2-A (YRG 2-A), Records of the Yale president's office.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The materials were transferred from the Association of Yale Alumni, 2008.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This materials are open for research.

Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright for materials authored or otherwise produced as official business of Yale University is retained by Yale University. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: DeVane Lecture Series, Yale University, Audiorecordings (RU 1069). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Yale University records are arranged and described at the accession level by the creating office. The University Archives creates collection level descriptive records, but typically does no further arrangement and description at the accession level.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The DeVane lectures were established in 1969 in honor of William Clyde DeVane, dean of Yale College from 1939 to 1963. The series has traditionally covered a different topic each year, ranging from democracy to Yale's role in the 20th century. The lecture series is organized and financed by the President's Office and is open to the general public as well as to Yale students. Only Yale students though are permitted to attend the discussion sections, and the lecture series counts as a full Yale credit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials consist of audiorecordings of lectures and discussion sessions from Yale University's DeVane Lecture Series.

did.unittitle: Nancy F. Cott, Stanley Woodward Professor of History and American Studies
Gaddis Smith, Professor of History,"Yale and the External World: the Shaping of the University in the 20th Century"
Anthony Kronman, Dean of the Yale Law School, "The Democratic Soul,"audiocassette (87 minutes)
David Bromwich, Bird White Housum Professor of English, "Abraham Lincoln and Walt Whitman as Representative Americans," audiocassette(62 minutes)

Mahzarin Banaji, Reuben Post halleck Professor of Psychology, "Paradoxes of Mind and Society: The Bounded Nature of Cognition and the Unbounded Possibilities for American Democracy," audiocassette (45 minutes)
Ian Shapiro, William R. Kenan, Jr. Professor and Chairman, Political Science, "Democracy and Distribution," audiocassette (66 minutes)
Richard C. Levin, President of Yale and Frederick William Beinecke Professor of Economics, "Democracy and the Market," audiocassette (69 minutes)

Michael Denning, Professor of American Studies and Chair of the Program in Ethnicity, Race and Migration, "Neither Capitalist nor American: The Democracy as Social Movement," audiocassette (59 minutes)
Bruce Ackerman, Sterling Professor of Law and Political Science, "The Death of Citizenship?" audiocassette (66 minutes)
Joan A. Steitz, Sterling Professor of Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry, "American Democracy and the Origins of the Biomedical Revolution," audiocassette (74 minutes)
David Gelernter, Professor of Computer Science, "Democracy and Computers -- Pitfalls, Possibilities," audiocassette (51 minutes)
Richard Brodhead, Dean of Yale College and A.Bartlett Giamatti Professor of English and Professor of American Studies, "Democracy and Education," audiocassette (62 minutes)
Nancy F. Cott, Sterling Professor of History, "Democracy and the Family," audiocassette (55 minutes)
Stephen L. Carter, William Nelson Cromwell Professor of Law, "Can Religion Tolerate Democracy (and Vice Versa)?" audiocassette (68 minutes)
John Lewis Gaddis, Robert A. Lovett Professor of Military and Naval History, "Democracy and Foreign Policy," audiocassette (61 minutes)

James C. Scott, Eugene Meyer Professor of Political Science and Professor of Anthropology, "Meritocracy and Democracy: The Temptations of Mechanical, "Objective," and Impersonal Measures of Quality," audiocassette (69 minutes)
Richard Benson, Dean of the School of Art, Professor of Photography, "Pictures for the People: Visual Multiples and their Role as Supporting Tools for the Democratic Process" [not received]
Robert A.M. Stern, Dean School of Architecture, "Ideals Without Ideologies: Yale's Contribution to Modern Architecture"
